note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Electromagnetic navigational bronchoscopy with radial EBUS and fluoroscopic guidance for biopsy of a left upper lobe nodule.
Patient: David Brown, 59-year-old male, active smoker, with 22 mm PET-avid LUL nodule.
Sedation: Moderate sedation using midazolam and fentanyl; native airway with bite block and spontaneous ventilation.
Navigation: SuperDimension electromagnetic platform used. CT-based planning and registration via anatomical landmarks. Registration error approximately 4 mm.
Radial EBUS: Eccentric view of solid lesion obtained.
Sampling: Tool position confirmed by fluoroscopy only. Five forceps biopsies and two brushings performed. No cryobiopsy. ROSE with atypical cells suspicious for malignancy.
Complications: Minor bleeding controlled with iced saline and epinephrine; no desaturation. No pneumothorax on fluoroscopic screening.
Sedation reversal: Naloxone administered at end of case for slow emergence.
Disposition: Observed for 2 hours and discharged home with instructions for urgent return if hemoptysis or dyspnea.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Biopsy of PET-avid left upper lobe pulmonary nodule
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: 22 mm peripheral LUL nodule with bronchus sign and increased uptake on PET
registry_entry.lesion_location: Left upper lobe apicoposterior peripheral nodule
registry_entry.ebus_rose_result: Atypical cells suspicious for malignancy from forceps biopsies
registry_entry.bronch_indication: ENB and radial EBUS-guided biopsy of LUL nodule
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Suspicious for malignancy; final pathology pending
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Follow-up in lung nodule clinic in 1 week to review results

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Monarch robotic-assisted navigational bronchoscopy with radial EBUS, cryobiopsy, and forceps biopsies of a right middle lobe nodule.
Patient: Angela White, 63-year-old female with 14 mm PET-avid RML nodule in a never-smoker.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia via 8.0 mm ETT, pressure control ventilation.
Navigation: Monarch platform with CT-based virtual bronchoscopy. Registration completed with 2.5 mm error. Radial EBUS with concentric view at target.
Sampling: Tool-in-lesion confirmed by cone-beam CT. Four cryobiopsies using 1.1 mm cryoprobe and four standard forceps biopsies were obtained. ROSE suggested possible metastatic adenocarcinoma.
Complications: Mild bleeding controlled with occlusion and iced saline. Small right apical pneumothorax noted on immediate postprocedure CXR requiring pigtail chest tube placement.
Disposition: Patient observed overnight on telemetry with chest tube to water seal.

registry_entry.ebus_rose_result: Cryobiopsy with atypical gland-forming cells concerning for adenocarcinoma
registry_entry.nav_rebus_view: Concentric radial EBUS view at lesion
registry_entry.nav_imaging_verification: Cone-beam CT confirmed tool within lesion
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Robotic navigational bronchoscopy for RML nodule with cryobiopsy

registry_entry.bronch_immediate_complications: Small pneumothorax treated with pigtail chest tube; mild bleeding only
registry_entry.pneumothorax_intervention: Right pigtail chest tube to water seal
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Preliminary pathology suggests metastatic adenocarcinoma; final stains pending
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Repeat CXR in the morning; outpatient oncology follow-up after final pathology

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedures: (1) Rigid bronchoscopy with mechanical debulking, (2) Argon plasma coagulation, (3) Silicone stent placement.
Patient: Michael Green, 72-year-old male with severe dyspnea from distal tracheal tumor causing critical central airway obstruction.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia, rigid bronchoscope size 12 with coaxial 7.0 ETT, pressure control ventilation.
Findings: Exophytic tumor arising from distal trachea extending to main carina with approximately 90 percent luminal obstruction.
Interventions: Mechanical coring of tumor using rigid barrel and forceps, followed by argon plasma coagulation of residual tumor. Final obstruction estimated at less than 10 percent. A 14 x 50 mm silicone straight stent was placed across the distal trachea and main carina under bronchoscopic guidance.
Complications: Transient hypotension during induction treated with vasopressor bolus; no airway complications. EBL 50 mL.
Disposition: Patient remained intubated and was transferred to ICU for overnight observation.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Critical central airway obstruction from distal tracheal tumor
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: CT chest showing near-complete distal tracheal obstruction by intraluminal mass
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Palliative external beam radiation (completed 6 months ago)
registry_entry.cao_primary_modality: Rigid mechanical debulking and argon plasma coagulation
registry_entry.cao_tumor_location: Distal trachea at and above main carina
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Therapeutic rigid bronchoscopy for malignant central airway obstruction
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Tumor debulked tissue sent for histology only
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Known squamous cell carcinoma, debulking only; no new diagnosis targeted
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: ICU monitoring; oncology follow-up for further palliative care planning

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedures: Rigid bronchoscopy with tumor debulking and placement of covered metallic stent in left mainstem bronchus.
Patient: Linda Davis, 69-year-old female with left mainstem obstruction from endobronchial adenocarcinoma causing collapse of left lung.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia via rigid bronchoscope size 11 with jet ventilation.
Findings: Friable tumor completely occluding left mainstem bronchus at its origin.
Intervention: Mechanical debulking using rigid barrel, suction, and forceps until lumen opened. Argon plasma coagulation applied to tumor base. Residual obstruction approximately 20 percent. A 12 x 40 mm covered self-expanding metallic stent was deployed under bronchoscopic and fluoroscopic guidance into the left mainstem.
Complications: None. EBL 30 mL.
Disposition: Extubated and transferred to PACU on 2 L nasal cannula. Postprocedure CXR showed re-expansion of left lung.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Malignant central airway obstruction of left mainstem bronchus
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: CT chest with complete left lung atelectasis and obstructing left mainstem mass
registry_entry.cao_primary_modality: Rigid mechanical debulking with argon plasma coagulation
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Therapeutic rigid bronchoscopy for malignant left mainstem obstruction
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Known adenocarcinoma; central airway stenting performed for palliation
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Repeat CXR in 24 hours and clinic follow-up in 2 weeks to assess stent position and symptoms

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscopy with cryotherapy and mechanical debulking for endobronchial tumor.
Patient: Samuel Ortiz, 55-year-old male with endobronchial tumor in right mainstem causing moderate obstruction.
Anesthesia: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl; native airway with bite block.
Findings: Polypoid tumor arising from right mainstem bronchus causing approximately 70 percent obstruction.
Intervention: Multiple cycles of cryotherapy applied using flexible cryoprobe followed by mechanical debulking with forceps and suction. Residual obstruction estimated at 20 percent. No stent placed.
Complications: Mild oozing controlled with cold saline and epinephrine instillation. No hypoxia.
Disposition: Recovered in bronchoscopy unit and discharged home the same day with close oncology follow-up.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Symptomatic central airway obstruction of right mainstem bronchus
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: CT chest with irregular right mainstem endobronchial mass and distal air trapping
registry_entry.anesthesia_agents: Midazolam, fentanyl, nebulized and topical lidocaine
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Therapeutic debulking of right mainstem endobronchial tumor
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Debulked tumor fragments sent for histology
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Repeat bronchoscopy if symptoms recur; consider radiation or systemic therapy per oncology

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction with Zephyr endobronchial valves to left upper lobe.
Patient: Karen Young, 68-year-old female with severe emphysema and hyperinflation despite maximal medical therapy.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with 8.0 mm ETT, volume control ventilation.
Target selection: Left upper lobe selected based on CT fissure analysis and perfusion imaging showing heterogeneous emphysema.
Collateral ventilation assessment: Chartis performed in LUL segments with absence of collateral ventilation.
Intervention: Three Zephyr valves placed in LUL segments (LB1+2, LB3). Post-deployment airway inspection confirmed good seal.
Complications: None. Minimal secretions cleared. No pneumothorax on immediate CXR.
Disposition: Admitted overnight for observation, early ambulation, and serial chest radiographs.

registry_entry.note_text:

registry_entry.primary_indication: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction for severe LUL-predominant emphysema
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: CT with heterogeneous emphysema, most severe in LUL; intact fissures; hyperinflation on lung volumes
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Maximal inhaler therapy and pulmonary rehabilitation
registry_entry.blvr_chartis_result: No collateral ventilation detected in LUL
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction for emphysema
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Severe heterogeneous emphysema treated with BLVR valves
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Daily CXRs for 2 days and clinic follow-up in 4 weeks with PFTs

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction using Spiration valves targeting right upper lobe.
Patient: Thomas Baker, 61-year-old male with GOLD IV COPD and RUL-predominant emphysema.
Sedation: Monitored anesthesia care with propofol infusion.
Target selection: Right upper lobe based on CT fissure analysis; Chartis not performed.
Intervention: Two Spiration valves placed in RUL segments (RB1 and RB2+3). There was good collapse of RUL airways on bronchoscopy.
Complications: None during procedure. No immediate pneumothorax on CXR.
Disposition: Admitted overnight for observation.

registry_entry.radiographic_findings: CT showing severe emphysema in RUL with relatively intact fissures; hyperinflation on lung volumes
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Maximal medical therapy and pulmonary rehab
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Advanced emphysema treated with BLVR to RUL
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: CXR at 4 and 24 hours; clinic follow-up at 4 weeks with spirometry

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction with Zephyr valves to left lower lobe in heterogeneous emphysema.
Patient: Emily Rogers, 70-year-old female with severe dyspnea and LLL-predominant emphysema.
Sedation: General anesthesia with ETT.
Target selection: Left lower lobe based on CT and perfusion imaging. Chartis performed with low but persistent airflow suggesting borderline collateral ventilation; decision made to proceed with caution.
Intervention: Two Zephyr valves placed in LLL segments. Endoscopic assessment showed good valve seating.
Complications: Transient desaturation to 86 percent corrected with increased FiO2. No pneumothorax on immediate CXR.
Disposition: Admitted to monitored bed for observation.

registry_entry.primary_indication: BLVR for left lower lobe predominant emphysema
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Heterogeneous emphysema, LLL-predominant, hyperinflation on PFTs
registry_entry.blvr_chartis_result: Borderline collateral ventilation with low but persistent airflow
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Severe emphysema treated with BLVR to LLL
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Daily CXR and outpatient pulmonary follow-up in 1 month with PFTs

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Whole lung lavage (left lung) for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis.
Patient: Brian Scott, 42-year-old male with confirmed autoimmune pulmonary alveolar proteinosis and progressive dyspnea.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with double-lumen endotracheal tube for single-lung ventilation.
Procedure details: Left lung lavaged using warm saline aliquots of 750 to 1000 mL with manual chest percussion. Total instilled volume 30 L; total effluent 25 L of progressively clearer, initially milky return.
Complications: Transient hypotension treated with fluids and vasopressors; oxygenation maintained with right lung ventilation.
Disposition: Patient remained intubated at end of case and was transported to ICU for overnight ventilatory support and monitoring.

registry_entry.note_text:

registry_entry.primary_indication: Therapeutic whole lung lavage for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: CT with diffuse crazy-paving opacities and ground-glass opacities
registry_entry.prior_therapy: GM-CSF inhalation therapy with inadequate response
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Whole lung lavage for alveolar proteinosis
registry_entry.bronch_guidance: Flexible bronchoscopy for airway clearance and confirmation of DLT position
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis treated with left whole lung lavage
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Planned right lung lavage in 1 to 2 weeks depending on recovery

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Whole lung lavage (right lung) for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis.
Patient: Olivia Perez, 37-year-old female with autoimmune PAP status post left lung lavage 2 weeks ago.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with double-lumen ET tube.
Procedure details: Right lung lavaged with warm saline aliquots of 800 to 1000 mL. Total instilled volume 36 L with 30 L clear return by the end of lavage. Effluent initially milky, becoming progressively clear.
Complications: Brief desaturation to low 80s during large aliquot, improved with temporary pause and recruitment maneuvers.
Disposition: Extubated in OR and transported to ICU on high-flow nasal cannula for monitoring.

registry_entry.note_text:

registry_entry.primary_indication: Right whole lung lavage for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Diffuse ground-glass opacities with crazy-paving pattern, improved on left after prior lavage
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Left lung lavage completed successfully 2 weeks prior
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Right whole lung lavage for alveolar proteinosis
registry_entry.bronch_guidance: Flexible bronchoscopy to confirm DLT position and clear secretions
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis status post bilateral whole lung lavage
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Wean to ward as tolerated; follow-up imaging in 6 to 8 weeks
